title: 115_s12
content: The Act titled "Increasing the Department of Veterans Affairs Accountability to Veterans Act of 2017" focuses on holding leaders accountable for managing the Department of Veterans Affairs. The "Increasing the Department of Veterans Affairs Accountability to Veterans Act of 2017" introduces a new section for an annual performance plan for political appointees in the Department, similar to career appointees in the Senior Executive Service, focusing on goals like recruiting and retaining qualified individuals. The Department of Veterans Affairs aims to improve employee engagement, training, development, and accountability for managers. This is part of the "Increasing the Department of Veterans Affairs Accountability to Veterans Act of 2017." The Department of Veterans Affairs is focused on improving employee engagement, training, development, and accountability for managers through the "Increasing the Department of Veterans Affairs Accountability to Veterans Act of 2017." Additionally, there is a provision for an annual performance plan for political appointees. During the probationary period at the Department of Veterans Affairs, supervisors must assess employees' performance and decide if they should continue past the probationary period. Employees cannot complete the probationary period unless successful performance is demonstrated. During the probationary period at the Department of Veterans Affairs, supervisors must assess employees' performance to determine if they can continue. If no decision is made within 60 days after the initial 30-day period, the employee is considered to have completed the probationary period. During the probationary period at the Department of Veterans Affairs, supervisors assess employees' performance. An affirmative determination made after the 30-day period means the employee completed probation retroactively. The Secretary must notify Congress monthly about instances where a supervisor fails to make a required determination. During a probationary period at the Department of Veterans Affairs, supervisors must assess employees' performance. If a supervisor fails to make a required determination within the specified period, they must still address previous instances in subsequent notifications. Supervisors of employees in probationary positions must demonstrate management competencies in addition to technical skills. Annual performance plans for supervisors must include providing regular feedback to employees before making determinations. During a probationary period, supervisors at the Department of Veterans Affairs must assess employees' performance and make timely determinations. The term "supervisor" is defined in section 7103(a) of title 5, United States Code. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs must ensure that managers are evaluated on addressing employee performance and misconduct, as well as improving employee engagement. Additionally, employees terminating their employment with the Department of Veterans Affairs must provide a written opinion on certain employment restrictions. Before terminating employment with the Department of Veterans Affairs, officials involved in significant acquisitions must obtain a written opinion from an ethics counselor regarding restrictions on activities for two years after termination. The term "covered contractor" refers to a contractor working on a contract with the Department. The term "covered contractor" refers to a contractor working on a contract with the Department of Veterans Affairs. SEC. 6. Requirement for contractors of the Department employing certain recently separated Department employees. Requirement for contractors employing certain recently separated Department employees: A covered contractor cannot provide compensation to a Department official for two years after their termination unless they have obtained a required written opinion. The subsection defines a covered contractor as one who enters into a contract with the Department exceeding $10,000,000. The requirement applies to entities entering into contracts with the Department after the enactment of the Act. A clerical amendment is made to the table of sections in the title. Requirement for contractors employing certain recently separated Department employees. Passed the Senate on May 25, 2017. Attest: JULIE E. ADAMS, Secretary.
